marc:datafield.marc:subfield: John H. Hartman was a resident of Rowan County, North Carolina and a Confederate soldier.
Personal letters from John Hartman to his wife.
Charles L. Harrison was one of the early American settlers in Texas.
Titles and deeds to land in Jackson and Liberty counties, Texas, several of which are in Spanish.
Henry Harrison was a slave owner of Berkeley County, West Virginia.
Collection contains letters chiefly concerning the settlement of Harrison's estate, including the sale of furniture and slaves; one African American was to be freed and sent to Liberia.
William F. Harrison was a Confederate officer with the 23rd Regiment, Virginia Volunteers, from Goochland County, Virginia.

Letters from Harrison to his wife describing fighting in western Virginia under generals Garnett and Loring and in the Shenandoah Valley under Jackson; training and discipline; health and sanitary conditions in camps; hardships of army life; furloughs and enlistments. Two letters of 1871-1872 concern railroad construction in West Virginia.
James H. Harrison was from Caswell County, North Carolina. He died from typhoid fever in Richmond, Virginia, while in the Confederate army.
Personal letters, some of which were written while Harrison was a soldier.
Jesse Harrison was a Union-sympathizer, from New Bern (Craven County), North Carolina.

Civil War letters written by a "buffalo" (a coastal dweller in North Carolina who sympathized with the Federal forces) behind the Federal lines at Washington, North Carolina; and letters written after the war describing the financial difficulties of the Harrison family.
George Paul Harrison wa a soldier and politician of Savannah, Georgia.

One letter from George Paul Harrison to Governor Joseph E. Brown concerning an illegal distillery in the Savannah River swamp; and one from Harrison to C. C. Jones, Jr., regarding the latter's address to the Augusta (Georgia) Confederate Survivors' Association.
Jefferson Hartman was a Union soldier, from Shamokin Dam (Snyder County), Pennsylvania.

Civil War correspondence of brothers Jefferson and Samuel P. Hartman, discussing camp life, concern for home affairs, and the effects of Lincoln's assassination. Samuel was in the 49th Regiment, Pennsylvania Volunteers, and was stationed at Petersburg, Va.
James Thomas Harrison was an ex-Confederate congressman, who resided in Columbus, Mississippi.

A letter from Harrison to his wife telling her that he will not be permitted to take his seat in the U.S. House of Representatives after having been elected upon the return of Mississippi to the Union.
